newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money quoted higher, gilts sharply up.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money quoted higher, gilts sharply up.

text.p: Indian call money was quoted in the 4.0-4.5 percent range in early trade Thursday but few trades were done as it was the fortnightly reporting day for banks, dealers said.
Call money ended Wednesday at 0.75-1.25 percent.
Dealers said call money opened higher on Thursday on higher quotes by lenders seeking to push up rates after Wednesday's central bank auctions of government securities.
The RBI mopped up 11.79 billion rupees at an auction of 364-day treasury bills and 30 billion at a six-year bond auction.
"Lenders are trying to drive rates up," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "But very few deals will be struck today as it is the reporting day."
Dealers said prices of government securities rose in early deals, after the RBI set a lower than expected cut-off yield at Wednesday's six-year bond auction.
The RBI set a cut-off of 11.83 percent against market expectations of 11.90-11.95.
"Prices are realigning on the new security," said a dealer. "Prices will be firm today and may rise further."
The 11.83 percent 2003 bond auctioned at par on Wednesday traded on Thursday at 101.25 rupees, dealers said.
Among other securities, the 12.59 percent 2004 rose to 104 rupees from its last traded price of 102.90 and the 12.50 percent 2004 jumped to 103.80 rupees from 102.75.
